figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Overall compliance percentage as a function of year of publication of organismal animal physiology articles (n = 84) published in five different journals: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology Part B, Journal of Physiology, Journal of Experimental Biology, American Journal of Physiology—Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative, and Frontiers in Physiology. See methods for additional details. Capital letters indicate significant differences among years. Mean value for decade group 2018–2020 (n = 45) is significantly higher than decade group 2008–2010 (n = 39; P = 0.001).

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Overall reporting compliance of 34 commonly reported experimental variables, from highest to lowest compliance relative to mean compliance of ∼63%. Data are grouped into data collection variables (gray), innate biological variables (red), and experimental condition variables (blue) and are likely to affect physiological processes and, consequently, the reported results. Note that 11 of 13 variables with less than average compliance involved factors potentially affecting the physiology of the study subject.

claims.sentence:
All statistical analyses were performed using SigmaPlot 14 (Systat Software, Inc., San Jose, CA).RESULTS
Overall Reporting Compliance of Study Experimental Variables
The average combined reporting compliance of all variables is presented in Figure 1.
The distribution of variables reported above and below average reporting compliance levels shows a clear pattern with regard to variable category (Fig. 2).
The 10 variables with lowest reporting compliance, on the other hand, comprise almost exclusively innate biological as well as experimental condition variables (Fig. 2).

Note that 11 of 13 variables with less than average compliance involved factors potentially affecting the physiology of the study subject.Compliance of Variables Explicitly Mentioned in ARRIVE Guidelines
The compliance rate for the 26 variables specified in the ARRIVE guidelines (see Table 1) was 69 ± 5% (mean ± SE), which was significantly (P = 0.045) higher than the 43 ± 10% compliance rate for the additional eight variables that we assessed that were not indicated in the ARRIVE guidelines.Compliance and Taxon in Analyzed Papers
Compliance values were calculated separately for four very general categories of taxa – humans, rodents (mostly mice and rats), other vertebrates (birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish), and invertebrates (Fig. 3).

As another example of a variable that may just be viewed as “not worth reporting,” the prandial state of experimental animals was underreported compared with many more overtly controlled variables (Fig. 2, Supplemental Table S1).
The distribution of variables reporting compliance levels shows a clear pattern with regard to variable category (Fig. 2).

That is, human studies show similar compliance rates to all other taxa (Fig. 3), refuting the idea that those working in clinical or biomedical settings are more careful in their reporting of variables.Can reporting compliance be increased…and how?
Notwithstanding possible limitations of the present investigation as a “case study,” our data show that most publications in animal experimental biology leave as undescribed numerous important unknowns.
Somewhat encouragingly, however, the year 2020 shows significantly higher reporting compliance (Fig. 1).

As another example of a variable that may just be viewed as “not worth reporting,” the prandial state of experimental animals was underreported compared with many more overtly controlled variables (Fig. 2, Supplemental Table S1).

That is, human studies show similar compliance rates to all other taxa (Fig. 3), refuting the idea that those working in clinical or biomedical settings are more careful in their reporting of variables.Can reporting compliance be increased…and how?
Notwithstanding possible limitations of the present investigation as a “case study,” our data show that most publications in animal experimental biology leave as undescribed numerous important unknowns.
Somewhat encouragingly, however, the year 2020 shows significantly higher reporting compliance (Fig. 1).
